a.g: Ta, Ha.
We have not sent down to you the Qur'an that you be distressed
But only as a reminder for those who fear [Allah] -
A revelation from He who created the earth and highest heavens,
The Most Merciful [who is] above the Throne established.
To Him belongs what is in the heavens and what is on the earth and what is between them and what is under the soil.
And if you speak aloud - then indeed, He knows the secret and what is [even] more hidden.
Allah - there is no deity except Him. To Him belong the best names.
And has the story of Moses reached you? -
When he saw a fire and said to his family, "Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire; perhaps I can bring you a torch or find at the fire some guidance."
And when he came to it, he was called, "O Moses,
Indeed, I am your Lord, so remove your sandals. Indeed, you are in the sacred valley of Tuwa.

Indeed, just as you comprehend the establishment of the quest for knowledge [talab al-'ilm] and its intention within the very essence of the father for the child before his child is createdâ€”so that when his child is created, becomes rational, and God creates for him a knowledge [ma'rifa] pertaining to what is in the heart [qalb] of his father from that questâ€”he then becomes commanded by that quest which was established in the very essence of his father and whose existence continued until the time of his child's knowledge [ma'rifa] of it. So, comprehend the establishment of the quest which His word, Mighty and Majestic, indicated: "Take off your sandals," within the very essence of God, and the arrival of Moses, peace be upon him, being addressed by it after his existence, since a knowledge [ma'rifa] of that quest was created for him and he heard that Eternal Speech.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Prayer
Indeed, the apparent command necessitates obligation, and heedlessness [ghafla] opposes remembrance [dhikr]. So how can one who is heedless throughout all of his prayer be establishing the prayer for My remembrance? (The Virtue of Humility [khushu']) "Indeed, I am Allah. There is no deity except Me, so worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance." (20:14) And He, the Exalted, said: "And do not be among the heedless [ghafilin]." (7:205) And He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "Do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated [sukara] until you know what you are saying." (4:43) It is said: 'intoxicated from the multitude of concerns,' and it is said: 'from the love of the world [dunya].' And Wahb said: 'What is intended is its apparent meaning.' So in it is an alert to the intoxication of the world [dunya], for He stated the reason within it, saying: "until you know what you are saying." (4:43) And how many a person praying [musalli] has not drunk wine, yet he does not know what he is saying in his prayer! And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever prays two units [rak'atayn] without conversing with himself therein about anything of the world [dunya], his preceding sins are forgiven for him." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Verily, prayer [salah] is restraint, humility, supplication, sighing, remorse, and placing your hands [in supplication] while you say: 'O Allah, O Allah.' So whoever does not do that, then it is deficient." And it is narrated from Allah, glorified is He, in the previous scriptures that He said: 'I do not accept the prayer [salah] of every person praying [musalli]. I only accept the prayer [salah] of one who humbles himself before My majesty, does not act arrogantly over My servants, and feeds the hungry poor for the sake of My Face.' And he, peace be upon him, said: "Prayer [salah] was only prescribed, and the Hajj, circumambulation [tawaf], and the rites [manasik] were commanded, for the establishment of the remembrance [dhikr] of Allah, the Exalted. So if there is not in your heart [qalb] for the One Remembered [madhkur], who is the intended goal and objective, any majesty or awe, then what is the value of your remembrance [dhikr]?" And he, peace be upon him, said to the one he advised: "And when you pray, pray the prayer [salah] of one bidding farewell." Meaning, bidding farewell to his soul [nafs], bidding farewell to his desire [hawa], bidding farewell to his lifespan, journeying to his Master, as He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "O mankind, indeed you are laboring toward your Lord with [great] exertion and will meet Him." (84:6) And He, the Exalted, said: "And fear Allah; and Allah teaches you." (2:282) And He, the Exalted, said: "And fear Allah and know that you will meet Him." (2:223) And he, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever is not prevented by his prayer [salah] from immorality and wrongdoing, he only increases in distance from Allah." And prayer [salah] is a confidential discourse [munajat]; so how can it be with heedlessness [ghafla]?

And he, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, prayer [salah] is humility [tamassuk], and lowliness [tawadu'], and supplication [tadarru'], and sighing [ta'awwuh], and remorse [tanadum], and you place your hands and say: O Allah, O Allah. So whoever does not do that, then it is deficient [khidaj]." And it is narrated from Allah, glorified is He, in the previous scriptures that He said: "Not every person who prays do I accept his prayer. I only accept the prayer of one who humbles himself before My majesty and does not act arrogantly towards My servants, and feeds the hungry poor for My sake." He said: "You perfect your ablution and enter your prayer niche [mihrab], and there you are, you have entered upon your Master [Mawla] without permission and speak to Him without an interpreter." It is narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: (Indeed, Allah the Exalted glorifies Himself every day and says: 'Indeed, I am Allah, Lord of the worlds. Indeed, I am Allah, there is no god except Me, the Living, the Sustainer (Al-Qayyum). Indeed, I am Allah, there is no god except Me, the Most High, the Most Great. Indeed, I am Allah, there is no god except Me, I have not begotten nor have I been begotten. Indeed, I am Allah, there is no god except Me, the Pardoner, the Forgiving. Indeed, I am Allah, there is no god except Me, the Originator (Mubdi') of everything and to Me is the return, the Mighty, the Wise, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, Master of the Day of Judgment, Creator of good and evil, Creator of Paradise and Hell, the One, the Unique, the Single, the Eternal (As-Samad) who has not taken a consort nor a son, the Single, the Odd, Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, the Sovereign, the Holy, the Peace, the Faithful, the Guardian, the Mighty, the Compeller, the Majestic, the Creator, the Maker, the Fashioner, the Great, the Exalted, the Powerful, the Subduer, the Forbearing, the Generous, Possessor of praise and glory, Knower of the secret and what is more hidden, the Able, the Provider, above the creation and the creatures[135]). And He mentioned before every word 'Indeed, I am Allah, there is no god except Me' as we have brought it in the beginning. So whoever supplicates with these names, let him say: 'Indeed, You are Allah, there is no god except You, such and such.' So whoever supplicates with them is written among the prostrating, the humble (Mukhbiteen) who will be neighbors to Muhammad, Ibrahim, Musa, Isa, and the prophets, prayers of Allah be upon them, in the abode of majesty, and for him is the reward of the worshippers in the heavens and the earths. And may Allah send blessings upon Muhammad and upon every chosen servant (Abd Mustafa).

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Companionship
As for the sinner (Fasiq) who persists in sinfulness, there is no benefit in his companionship because whoever fears Allah does not persist in major sin, and whoever does not fear Allah, his harm cannot be secured against nor can his friendship be trusted; rather, he changes with changing objectives. And Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our Remembrance (Dhikr) and who follows his desire (Hawa).' And Allah the Exalted said: 'So let not one who does not believe in it and follows his desire (Hawa) turn you away from it, lest you perish.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And turn away from him who turns away from Our Remembrance (Dhikr) and desires not except the worldly life.' And He said: 'And follow the way of him who turns to Me.' And in the understanding of that is a prohibition from the sinner (Fasiq).

a.g: And what is that in your right hand, O Moses?"
He said, "It is my staff; I lean upon it, and I bring down leaves for my sheep and I have therein other uses."
[Allah] said, "Throw it down, O Moses."
So he threw it down, and thereupon it was a snake, moving swiftly.
[Allah] said, "Seize it and fear not; We will return it to its former condition.
And draw in your hand to your side; it will come out white without disease - another sign,
That We may show you [some] of Our greater signs.
Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
And sometimes one may have a correct purpose and seeks evidence for it from the Quran, and he deduces from what he knows is not intended by it, like one who calls to seeking forgiveness (Istighfar) at the pre-dawn hours (Al-Ashar) and deduces from His saying: 'Take the pre-dawn meal (Tasahharu) for indeed in the pre-dawn meal (Al-Suhur) there is blessing' and claims that what is intended by it is taking the pre-dawn meal with remembrance (Dhikr), while he knows that what is intended by it is eating. And like one who calls to struggling against (Mujahada) the hard heart (Qalb) and says: 'Allah the Exalted said: "Go to Pharaoh, indeed he has transgressed"' and he points to his heart and indicates that it is what is intended by Pharaoh. And this type may be used by some preachers for correct purposes, beautifying the speech and encouraging the listener, and it is prohibited. And it may be used by the Batiniyya (esotericists) for corrupt purposes to deceive people and invite them to their false doctrine, so they interpret the Quran according to their opinion and doctrine regarding matters they know with certainty are not intended by it. So these arts are one aspect of the prohibition of interpretation by opinion (Tafsir bi al-Ra'y), and what is meant by opinion is the corrupt opinion that conforms to desire (Hawa) without correct independent reasoning (Ijtihad). And opinion encompasses both correct and corrupt, and what conforms to desire may be specifically named as opinion.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Tawhid and Trust
He fell unconscious, trembling in his swoon. When he regained consciousness, he said: 'Glory be to You, how great is Your affair! I repent to You, rely upon You, and believe that You are the King, the Compeller, the One, the Subduer. So I fear none but You, hope for none but You, and seek refuge only in Your pardon from Your punishment and in Your pleasure from Your wrath. I have nothing except to ask You, supplicate to You, and implore before You. So I say: "Expand for me my chest (SADR) to know You, and untie a knot from my tongue (LISAN) to praise You." Then he was called from behind the veil: "Beware of aspiring to praise and exceeding the Master of the Prophets. Rather, return to him: what he gives you, take it; what he forbids you from, abstain from it; and what he says to you, say it. For he did not increase in this Presence (HADRA) beyond saying: 'Glory be to You, I cannot enumerate praise upon You; You are as You have praised Yourself.'" He said: 'My God, if the tongue (LISAN) has no boldness to praise You, then does the heart (QALB) have aspiration in knowing You?' Then he was called: 'Beware of overstepping the necks of the Truthful Ones (SIDDIQIN). Return to the Greatest Truthful One (SIDDIQ AL-AKBAR) and follow him. For the companions of the Master of the Prophets are like stars: by whichever you follow, you are guided. Have you not heard him say: "Inability to grasp perception (IDRAK) is perception (IDRAK)." So suffice you a portion from Our Presence (HADRA) that you know you are deprived from Our Presence (HADRA), unable to observe Our beauty (JAMAL) and majesty (JALAL).' At that, the traveler (SALIK) returned and apologized for his questions and reproaches.

Go, you and your brother, with My signs and do not slacken in My remembrance.
Go, both of you, to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed.

And with this, when the magicians threw their magic, Moses felt fear in his Soul (Nafs) since he did not feel secure from the plotting (Makar) of Allah, and the matter became confused for him until reassurance was renewed for him and it was said to him: 'Do not fear, indeed you are the highest.' And whoever knows the reality (Haqiqah) of knowledge (Ma'rifah) [knows] the deficiency of his knowledge (Ma'rifah) from encompassing the reality (Kunh) of matters, his fear inevitably increases. And for that reason, Jesus said when it was said to him: 'Did you say to the people, "Take me and my mother as gods besides Allah"? He said, "Glory be to You! It is not for me to say what I have no right to. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within my Soul (Nafs), and I do not know what is within Your Soul (Nafs)."' And he said: 'If You punish them, indeed they are Your servants, and if You forgive them...' the verse. He entrusted the matter to the will (Mashiyyah) and removed himself entirely.

a.g: [Allah] said, "Fear not. Indeed, I am with you both; I hear and I see.

So go to him and say, 'Indeed, we are messengers of your Lord, so send with us the Children of Israel and do not torment them. We have come to you with a sign from your Lord. And peace will be upon he who follows the guidance.
Indeed, it has been revealed to us that the punishment will be upon whoever denies and turns away.' "
[Pharaoh] said, "So who is the Lord of you two, O Moses?"
He said, "Our Lord is He who gave each thing its form and then guided [it]."

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
As for guidance (Hidayah), there is no way for anyone to seek happiness except through it, because the inclination (DÄ'iyah) of a human may be inclined toward what contains rectification (SalÄh) of his Hereafter, but if he does not know what contains rectification of his Hereafter until he considers corruption (FasÄd) as rectification, then from where will mere will (IrÄdah) benefit him? So there is no benefit in will, capability (Qudrah), and means (AsbÄb) except after guidance (Hidayah). And therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'Our Lord is He Who gave to each thing its creation (Khalq), then guided (HidÄ)' (20:50). And He said: 'And were it not for the favor (Fadl) of Allah upon you and His mercy (Rahmah), none of you would ever have been purified (ZakkÄ), but Allah purifies whom He wills' (24:21). And He said (peace be upon him): 'No one enters Paradise except by the mercy (Rahmah) of Allah the Exalted, meaning by His guidance (HidÄyah).' It was said: 'Not even you, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'Not even me.' And guidance (HidÄyah) has three stations (ManÄzil): The first is knowledge of the path of good and evil, referred to by His saying: 'And We have guided him to the two ways (Najdayn)' (90:10). And Allah the Exalted has bestowed this upon all His servants, some of it through intellect ('Aql) and some of it upon the tongue of the messengers (Rusul). And therefore, He said: 'And as for Thamud, We guided them, but they preferred blindness ('AmÄ) over guidance (HudÄ)' (41:17). So the means (AsbÄb) of guidance (HudÄ) are the Book (KitÄb), the messengers (Rusul), and the insights (BasÄ'ir) of intellects ('UqÅ«l), and they are made available, and nothing prevents from them except envy (Hasad), arrogance (Kibr), love of the worldly life (Hubb al-DunyÄ), and the means (AsbÄb) that blind (Tu'mÄ«) the hearts (QulÅ«b) even though they do not blind the eyesights (AbsÄr). He said: 'For indeed, it is not the eyes that are blinded, but blinded are the hearts (QulÅ«b) which are within the breasts (SudÅ«r)' (22:46). And among the blinding things (Ma'miyyÄt) are familiarity (Ilf) and habit ('Ä€dah) and the love of adhering to them, and from it is the expression by His saying: 'Indeed, we found our fathers upon a community (Ummah)' (43:22) the verse. And from arrogance (Kibr) and envy (Hasad) is the expression by His saying: 'And they said, "Why was this Qur'an not sent down upon a great man from one of the two cities?"' (43:31) and His saying: 'Shall we follow one human being (Bashar) among us?' (54:24). So these blinding things (Ma'miyyÄt) are what prevented guidance-seeking (IhtidÄ') and guidance (HidÄyah).

a.g: [Pharaoh] said, "Then what is the case of the former generations?"
[Moses] said, "The knowledge thereof is with my Lord in a record. My Lord neither errs nor forgets."
[It is He] who has made for you the earth as a bed [spread out] and inserted therein for you roadways and sent down from the sky, rain and produced thereby categories of various plants.
Eat [therefrom] and pasture your livestock. Indeed, in that are signs for those of intelligence.
From the earth We created you, and into it We will return you, and from it We will extract you another time.

When his soul (Ruh) ascends, it is said: 'O Lord, Your servant so-and-so.' He says: 'Return him, and show him what I have prepared for him of honor, for I promised him: "From it (the earth) We created you, and into it We will return you, and from it We will bring you out another time" (Quran 20:55).' And indeed he hears the shuffling of their sandals when they turn away departing, until it is said: 'O you, who is your Lord, and what is your religion, and who is your prophet?' He says: 'My Lord is Allah, my religion is Islam, and my prophet is Muhammad (peace be upon him).' It is said: Then he is rebuked with a severe rebuke, and it is the last opportunity presented to the deceased. If he says that, a caller calls out: 'You have spoken truthfully,' and it is the meaning of His saying, the Exalted: "Allah keeps firm those who have believed with the firm word" (Quran 14:27).

a.g: And We certainly showed Pharaoh Our signs - all of them - but he denied and refused.
He said, "Have you come to us to drive us out of our land with your magic, O Moses?
Then we will surely bring you magic like it, so make between us and you an appointment, which we will not fail to keep and neither will you, in a place assigned."
[Moses] said, "Your appointment is on the day of the festival when the people assemble at mid-morning."
So Pharaoh went away, put together his plan, and then came [to Moses].
Moses said to the magicians summoned by Pharaoh, "Woe to you! Do not invent a lie against Allah or He will exterminate you with a punishment; and he has failed who invents [such falsehood]."
So they disputed over their affair among themselves and concealed their private conversation.
They said, "Indeed, these are two magicians who want to drive you out of your land with their magic and do away with your most exemplary way.
So resolve upon your plan and then come [forward] in line. And he has succeeded today who overcomes."
They said, "O Moses, either you throw or we will be the first to throw."
He said, "Rather, you throw." And suddenly their ropes and staffs seemed to him from their magic that they were moving [like snakes].
And he sensed within himself apprehension, did Moses.
Allah said, "Fear not. Indeed, it is you who are superior.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
And with this, when the magicians threw their magic, Moses felt in his soul (Nafs) apprehension since he did not feel secure from the deception (Makar) of Allah and the matter became confused for him until reassurance was renewed for him and it was said to him: 'Do not fear, indeed you are the highest.' And when the strength of the Muslims weakened on the day of Badr, he (the Prophet) said: 'O Allah, if You destroy this group, there will remain on the face of the earth no one who worships You.' So Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'Leave off your supplication to your Lord, for He is faithful to you with what He promised you.' So the station (Maqam) of the Truthful One (Al-Siddiq) (may Allah be pleased with him) was the station of trust (Thiqa) in the promise of Allah, and the station of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was the station of fear (Khauf) from the deception (Makar) of Allah, and it is more complete because it does not issue except from perfection of knowledge (Ma'rifah) of the secrets (Asrar) of Allah the Exalted and the hidden aspects (Khafa'ya) of His actions and the meanings (Ma'ani) of His attributes (Sifat) which some of what issues from them is expressed as deception (Makar), and no one from humankind has the ability to stand upon the reality (Kunh) of the attributes (Sifat) of Allah the Exalted. And whoever knows the reality (Haqiqah) of knowledge (Ma'rifah) [knows] the deficiency of his knowledge (Ma'rifah) from encompassing the reality (Kunh) of matters, his fear (Khauf) necessarily becomes great. And for that reason, Jesus (peace be upon him) said when it was said to him: 'Did you say to the people, "Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?" He said, "Exalted are You! It is not for me to say that to which I have no right. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within myself, and I do not know what is within Yourself."'

As for the one who has witnessed the path and traversed it himself, nothing is to be feared for him; rather, even if the veil were lifted, he would not increase in certainty (Yaqin), though he would increase in clarity. Just as one who sees a human at dawn does not increase in certainty at sunrise that it is a human, but increases in clarity regarding the details of his form. For the magicians of Pharaoh, because they were aware of the ultimate effect of magic due to their long observation and experience, saw from Moses, peace be upon him, what exceeded the limits of magic, and the truth of the matter was unveiled to them. Thus, they did not heed Pharaoh's statement, 'I will surely cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides,' but rather, 'They said: "We will never prefer you over what has come to us of the clear proofs and the One who created us. So decree whatever you are to decree. You can only decree for this worldly life."' For explanation (Bayan) and unveiling (Kashf) prevent change. As for the followers of the Samiri, since their faith was from looking at the apparent serpent, when they looked at the calf of the Samiri and heard its lowing, they changed and heard his saying, 'This is your god and the god of Moses,' and they forgot that it does not respond to them with speech, nor does it possess for them harm or benefit. Thus, everyone who believes by looking at a serpent will inevitably disbelieve if he looks at a calf, because both are from the world of witnessing (Alam al-Shahadah) and difference and opposition in the world of witnessing is abundant. As for the world of the dominion (Alam al-Malakut), it is from God, the Exalted, therefore we do not find in it any difference or opposition at all.

a.g: [Allah] said, "And what made you hasten from your people, O Moses?"
He said, "They are close upon my tracks, and I hastened to You, my Lord, that You be pleased."
[Allah] said, "But indeed, We have tried your people after you [departed], and the Samiri has led them astray."

So Moses returned to his people, angry and grieved. He said, "O my people, did your Lord not make you a good promise? Then, was the time [of its fulfillment] too long for you, or did you wish that wrath from your Lord descend upon you, so you broke your promise [of obedience] to me?"

They said, "We did not break our promise to you by our will, but we were made to carry burdens from the ornaments of the people [of Pharaoh], so we threw them [into the fire], and thus did the Samiri throw."
And he extracted for them [the statue of] a calf which had a lowing sound, and they said, "This is your god and the god of Moses, but he forgot."

As for the companions of the Samiri, when their faith was based on looking at the apparent serpent, then when they looked at the calf of the Samiri and heard its lowing, they changed and heard his saying "This is your god and the god of Moses" and they forgot that it does not return to them any speech nor possesses for them any harm or benefit: For everyone who believes by looking at a serpent disbelieves inevitably if he looks at a calf, because both are from the world of testimony (al-Shahadah) and difference and opposition in the world of testimony (al-Shahadah) is abundant. As for the world of the dominion (al-Malakut), it is from Allah the Exalted, therefore we do not find in it any difference or opposition at all.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
And its example is that one stands before a king from the kings all day long as is the custom of servants, yet his standing is only for observing a maiden from the maidens of the king or a boy from his boys. Indeed, this is mockery of the king, for he did not intend closeness to the king through his service, but rather intended by that a servant from his servants. So what contempt increases beyond that the servant intends by obedience to Allah the Exalted the showing-off (Riya') to a weak servant who does not possess for him harm nor benefit? And is that except because he thinks that that servant is more capable of attaining his objectives than Allah? And that he is more deserving of closeness to him than Allah since he preferred him over the King of Kings and made him the intended object of his worship? And what mockery increases beyond raising the servant above the Master (Mawla)? So this is from the great destructive sins, and for this the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) called it the minor polytheism (Shirk al-Asghar). Yes, some degrees of showing-off (Riya') are more severe than others - as will come its clarification in the degrees of showing-off (Riya') if Allah the Exalted wills - and nothing of it is devoid of grave or light sin according to what is in the showing-off (Riya'), and if there were not in showing-off (Riya') except that he prostrates and bows to other than Allah, it would be sufficient. For indeed, even if he did not intend closeness to Allah, he has intended other than Allah. By my life, if he magnified other than Allah with prostration, he would disbelieve with clear disbelief (Kufr Jali), except that showing-off (Riya') is the hidden disbelief (Kufr Khafi) because the show-off (Mura'i) has magnified in his heart (Qalb) the people, so that magnification necessitated that he prostrates and bows, so the people were the magnified ones by the prostration from one aspect. And whenever the intention of magnifying Allah by the prostration vanishes and the magnification of the creation (Khalq) remains, that was close to polytheism (Shirk), except that he intended the magnification of himself in the heart (Qalb) of the one magnified by him through his showing from himself the image of magnification for Allah. So from this it was hidden polytheism (Shirk Khafi), not clear polytheism (Shirk Jali), and that is the utmost ignorance, and none proceeds upon it except whom the Satan (Shaytan) has deceived and made him imagine that the servants possess from his harm and benefit.

a.g: And Aaron had already told them before [the return of Moses], "O my people, you are only being tested by it, and indeed, your Lord is the Most Merciful, so follow me and obey my order."
They said, "We will never cease being devoted to the calf until Moses returns to us."
[Moses] said, "O Aaron, what prevented you, when you saw them going astray,
From following me? Then have you disobeyed my order?"

[Aaron] said, "O son of my mother, do not seize [me] by my beard or by my head. Indeed, I feared that you would say, 'You caused division among the Children of Israel, and you did not observe [or await] my word.' "
[Moses] said, "And what is your case, O Samiri?"
He said, "I saw what they did not see, so I took a handful [of dust] from the track of the messenger and threw it, and thus did my soul entice me."

[Moses] said, "Then go. And indeed, it is [decreed] for you in [this] life to say, 'No contact.' And indeed, you have an appointment [in the Hereafter] you will not fail to keep. And look at your 'god' to which you remained devoted. We will surely burn it and blow it into the sea with a blast.
Your god is only Allah, except for whom there is no deity. He has encompassed all things in knowledge."

So O incapable reader, your share from your reading is only that you mumble the Quran and move your tongue with it, and if you were reflecting on what you read, you would be worthy of having your bitterness split open from what turned grey the hair of the master of the messengers, and if you are content with the movement of the tongue, you have been deprived of the fruit of the Quran. The Resurrection (Al-Qiyamah) is one of what is mentioned in it, and Allah has described some of its calamities and multiplied its names so that we may stand, through the multiplicity of its names, upon the multiplicity of its meanings, for the purpose of the multiplicity of names is not the repetition of names and titles, but the aim is to alert those of understanding (Ulul Albab), for under every name of the names of the Resurrection (Al-Qiyamah) there is a secret and in it...

Then look at how they are driven after the Resurrection (al-Ba'th) and the Rising (al-Nushur), barefoot, naked, uncircumcised, to the land of the Gathering (Ard al-Mahshar), a white land, a level plain, you will see in it no crookedness (la tara fiha 'iwajan) nor any depression (wa-la amtan), nor will you see upon it a hill behind which a human can hide, nor a valley that lowers from the eyes in it; rather, it is a single, simple, level ground with no variation in it; they are driven to it in groups. So glory be to the One who gathers the creatures despite the difference of their kinds from the corners of the earth when He drives them with the Shaking (al-Rajifah) followed by the Following (al-Radifah); and the Shaking is the first Blast (al-Nafkhah al-Ula) and the Following is the second Blast (al-Nafkhah al-Thaniyah). And it is fitting for those Hearts (Qulub) to be trembling (wajifah) at that time, and for those Eyes (Absar) to be humbled (khashi'ah). The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'The people will be gathered on the Day of Resurrection (Yawm al-Qiyamah) on a white, pale land like a pure loaf, with no landmark for anyone.' The narrator said: And the paleness is a whiteness that is not bright, and the pure is that which is pure from husk and bran, and landmark means no building to conceal nor variation to repel the sight. And do not think that that land is like the land of the world; rather, it does not equal it except in name. Allah the Exalted said: 'On the Day when the earth will be changed to another earth and the heavens.' Ibn Abbas said: It increases in it and decreases, and its trees, mountains, valleys, and what is in it go away, and it stretches like the stretching of the Adim al-'Akkazi, a white land like silver, upon which no blood has been spilled nor any sin committed; and the heavens, their sun, moon, and stars go away. So look, O wretched one, at the terror of that day and its severity, for when the creatures gather on this level ground, the stars of the sky scatter from above them and the sun is extinguished.

Vol 4: Meditation
And therefore it is said: 'Reflection (Tafakkur) for an hour is better than worship for a year.' It is said that it transfers from the disliked to the beloved, and from desire and greed to asceticism (Zuhd) and contentment (Qana'ah). And it is said that it brings about witnessing (Mushahadah) and piety (Taqwa). And therefore Allah the Exalted said: 'So that they may become pious (Yattaqun) or it may bring about for them a Remembrance (Dhikr).' And if you wish to understand how the state (Hal) changes through reflection (Fikr), its example is what we mentioned regarding the matter of the Hereafter. For reflection (Fikr) makes us know that the Hereafter is more deserving of preference. Is that due to a prior disobedience until it regresses to infinity, or it inevitably stops at a first cause that has no cause from the side of the servant? And about this meaning, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Adam and Moses (peace be upon them both) argued before their Lord, and Adam overcame Moses (peace be upon him). Moses said: 'You are Adam whom Allah created with His Hand, breathed into you from His Spirit (Ruh), made His angels prostrate to you, and settled you in His Garden, then you caused the people to descend to the earth by your sin.' Adam said: 'You are Moses whom Allah chose with His message and His speech, gave you the Tablets in which is the explanation of everything, and brought you near as a confidant. For how long did you find that Allah wrote the Torah before I was created?' Moses said: 'Forty years.' Adam said: 'Then did you find in it: "And Adam disobeyed (Ø¹ØµÙ‰) his Lord and went astray (ÙØºÙˆÙ‰)"? He said: 'Yes.' Adam said: 'Then do you blame me for doing an act that Allah wrote upon me before I did it and before He created me by forty years?' The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'So Adam overcame Moses.' So whoever knows the cause in this matter with a knowledge emanating from the light of guidance, he is from the special knowers (al-'arifin) who are aware of the secret of divine decree (al-qadr). And whoever hears this and believes in it and affirms it by mere hearing, he is from the general believers. And fear (khawf) occurs for each one of the two groups. For if he is a servant, he is fallen into the grasp of divine power like the fall of the weak child into the claws of the lion, and the lion may be heedless by coincidence and leave him, and it may attack him and devour him, and that is according to what coincides. And that coincidence has causes arranged by a known decree. But if it is attributed to one who does not know it, it is called coincidence, and if it is attributed to the knowledge of Allah, it is not permissible to call it coincidence. And the one fallen into the claws of the lion, if his knowledge were complete, he would not fear the lion because the lion is subjugated: if hunger is imposed upon it, it devours, and if heedlessness is imposed upon it, it leaves and abandons. So indeed, one fears the Creator of the lion and the Creator of its attributes. I do not say that the example of fear from Allah the Exalted is fear from the lion, but when the veil is lifted, it is known that fear from the lion is the very fear from Allah the Exalted because the destroyer through the medium of the lion is Allah. Now then: The greatest destroyer for the son of Adam is the desire (shahwa) of the stomach, for through it Adam (peace be upon him) and Eve were expelled from the abode of settlement to the abode of humiliation and need; when they were forbidden from the tree, their desires overcame them until they ate from it and their shameful parts became apparent to them. The stomach, in truth, is the spring of desires (shahawat) and the source of diseases and afflictions, for it is followed by the desire (shahwa) of the private parts and intense lust (shiddat al-shabaq) for women; then following the desire (shahwa) for food and intercourse comes intense craving for status and wealth, which are means to expansion in women and foods; then following the accumulation of wealth and status come various foolishnesses and types of rivalries and envies; then between them is generated the affliction of hypocrisy (riya') and the consequence of boasting, competition, and arrogance (kibriya'), then that leads to rancor, envy, enmity, and hatred, then that brings its possessor to plunge into oppression, evil, and indecency, and all of that is the fruit of neglecting the stomach and what is generated from it of the insolence of satiety and fullness. If the servant (al-'abd) had subdued his soul (nafs) with hunger and narrowed with it the channels of Satan, it would have submitted to the obedience of Allah (the Mighty and Majestic) and not taken the path of insolence and transgression, and it would not have led to immersion in the worldly life and preferring the immediate over the hereafter, and it would not have rushed with all this rushing upon the worldly life. And if the affliction of the desire (shahwa) of the stomach has reached this extent, it is obligatory to explain its dangers and afflictions as a warning from it, and it is obligatory to clarify the way of striving (mujahada) against it and to point out its virtue as an encouragement toward it, and likewise explaining the desire (shahwa) of the private parts, for it follows it.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
And as for mere movement of the tongue, it is of little benefit. Rather, the one who recites with the tongue while turning away from action is worthy of being what is intended by His saying, the Exalted: 'And whoever turns away from My Remembrance (Dhikr), then indeed for him is a straitened life (ma'ishatan dankan), and We will gather him on the Day of Resurrection blind.' And by His saying, the Exalted: 'Thus Our signs came to you, and you forgot them; and thus today you are forgotten.' That is, he left them and did not look at them and did not care for them. For the one who falls short in the matter, it is said that he forgot the matter. And the recitation of the Quran, its true recitation, is that the tongue, the intellect ('Aql), and the heart (Qalb) participate in it. Do you know regarding what was revealed "For him is a straitened life (ma'ishatan dankan)"? They said: Allah and His Messenger know best. He said: The punishment of the disbeliever in his grave; there are unleashed upon him ninety-nine dragons (tinnin). Do you know what the dragon (tinnin) is? And one should not be astonished at this number in particular, for the numbers of these snakes and scorpions are according to the number of blameworthy character traits (akhlaq al-madhmuma) from arrogance (kibr), hypocrisy (riya'), envy (hasad), rancor (ghill), malice (hiqd), and other attributes (sifat). For they have countable roots, then branches spread from them that are countable, then their branches divide into divisions, and those attributes in their very essences are the destroyers (al-muhlikat), and in their very essences they transform into scorpions and snakes. The strong among them stings with the sting of the dragon (tinnin), and the weak stings with the sting of the scorpion (aqrab), and what is between them harms with the harm of the snake (hayya). And the possessors of hearts (arbab al-qulub) and insights (al-basa'ir) witness with the light of insight (nur al-basira) these destroyers and their branching offshoots, except that the measure of their number cannot be ascertained except by the light of prophethood (nur al-nubuwwa). So, the likes of these reports have sound outward appearances (zawahir sahiha) and hidden secrets (asrar khafiya), but they are clear to the possessors of insights (arbab al-basa'ir). So, whoever the realities (haqa'iq) of them are not unveiled to him, he should not deny their outward appearances; rather, the lowest degrees of faith (iman) are belief (tasdiq) and submission (taslim).

They are five: The first: When the sun sets, he prays Maghrib and occupies himself with reviving what is between the two evening prayers (Isha), so the end of this devotional practice (Wird) is at the disappearance of the twilight, meaning the redness whose disappearance marks the entry of the time of the late evening prayer (Atama), and Allah the Exalted has sworn by it, saying: 'So I swear by the twilight' (Quran 89:1) {}, and the prayer in it is the beginning of the night because it is the first emergence of its hours, and it is a time (Anaa) from the times (Anaa) mentioned in the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'And from the times (Anaa) of the night, then glorify' (Quran 20:130) {}, and it is the prayer of the oft-returning ones (Al-Awabeen). That was narrated from Al-Hasan and Ibn Abi Ziyad attributed it to the Messenger of Allah ï·º (that he was asked about this verse and he ï·º said: The prayer between the two evening prayers, then he ï·º said: Upon you is the prayer between the two evening prayers, for it removes the frivolities (Malaghat) of the day and refines its end [42]). And 'Malaghat' is the plural of 'Malgha' from 'Laghw' (frivolity, idle talk). And Anas, may Allah have mercy on him, was asked about one who sleeps between the two evening prayers, and he said: Do not do it, for it is the hour intended by the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'Their sides forsake their beds' (Quran 32:16) {}. And the virtue of reviving what is between the two evening prayers will come in the second chapter. And the order of this devotional practice (Wird) is that he prays after Maghrib two units (Rak'atain) first, reciting in them 'Say, O disbelievers' (Surah Al-Kafirun) and 'Say, He is Allah, the One' (Surah Al-Ikhlas), and he prays them immediately after Maghrib without interruption of speech or occupation, then he prays four units (Arba'a) prolonging them, then he prays until the disappearance of the twilight what is easy for him, and if the mosque is near the house, then there is no harm in praying them in his house if his intention (Azm) is not to stay in the mosque, and if he intends to stay in waiting for the late evening prayer (Atama), then it is the best if he is safe from affectation (Tasannu') and showing off (Riya). So he sent me to a man from the Jews of Khaybar and said: "Say to him: Muhammad says to you: Lend me or sell me some flour until the crescent of Rajab." He said: So I came to him and he said: "No, by God, except with a pledge." So I informed the Messenger of God, peace and blessings of God be upon him, of that, and he said: "By God, I am indeed trustworthy [amin] with the people of the heaven, trustworthy [amin] with the people of the earth. And if he sold to me or lent to me, I would have fulfilled it to him. Go with this coat of mail of mine to him and pledge it to him." And when I went out, this verse was revealed: "And do not extend your eyes toward that by which We have given enjoyment to groups of them, as the glitter of the life of the world [zahrat al-hayat al-dunya]..." the verse. And this verse is a consolation [ta'ziyah] for the Messenger of God, peace and blessings of God be upon him, from the world [al-dunya].

a.g: And enjoin prayer upon your family [and people] and be steadfast therein. We ask you not for provision; We provide for you, and the [best] outcome is for [those of] righteousness.

a.g: And they say, "Why does he not bring us a sign from his Lord?" Has there not come to them evidence of what was in the former scriptures?

And if We had destroyed them with a punishment before him, they would have said, "Our Lord, why did You not send to us a messenger so we could have followed Your verses before we were humiliated and disgraced?"
Say, "Each [of us] is waiting; so wait. For you will know who are the companions of the sound path and who is guided."
